com.tlswe.awsmock.ec2.model

Class AbstractMockEc2Instance

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tlswe.awsmock.ec2.model.AbstractMockEc2Instance
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultMockEc2Instance

    public abstract class AbstractMockEc2Instance
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Generic class for mock ec2 instance, with basic simulation of behaviors and states of genuine ec2 instances' life cycle. Any extra implementation of more customized ec2 mock instances should extend this class (and override the events) and be defined as "ec2.instance.class" in aws-mock.properties (or if not overridden, as defined in aws-mock-default.properties). To simulate actual ec2 instances, we have an internal timer in each object of mock ec2 instance that continuously check and set the states of it, within the life cycle of start-pending-running-stopping-stopped-terminated for a single ec2 instance, and with random time deviations (e.g. random boot/shutdown time within predefined values).
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  AbstractMockEc2Instance.InstanceState
      Enumeration of all instance states.
      static class  AbstractMockEc2Instance.InstanceType
      Enumeration of all allowed instance types.
      class  AbstractMockEc2Instance.SerializableTimer
      We define Serializable Timer here because all members in AbstractMockEc2Instance need to be save to binary file as for persistence.

      Prefix for generated random public dnsname.
      static int TIMER_INTERVAL_MILLIS
      Interval for the internal timer thread that triggered for state chacking and changing - we set it for 10 seconds.

      • onInternalTimer

        public abstract void onInternalTimer()
        Triggered on arriving interval of the internal timer of mock ec2 instance.
        Note that if this method does things that take a long time, the interval would be prolonged and consequent events/state changing would always be delayed.
        See Also:
        TIMER_INTERVAL_MILLIS
